pageContext.title: The 10 Indian tech companies you should keep an eye on in 2019
pageContext.content:
2018 hasn’t ended yet, but India’s startup landscape is already proving more vibrant than last year. Investment more than doubled from 2017, achieving a total of US$4.3 billion from January to September 2018, according to a report from the National Association of Software and Services Companies.

India also added 1,200 new startups this year, the report stated. Eight of the country’s tech companies became unicorns – the most it has added in a calendar year – while more than 70 underwent mergers and acquisitions.

With such strong startup activity, India is a country to watch in 2019. Tech in Asia has picked out the top 10 local tech companies to look out for next year, based on the funding they received in 2018 and the plans they have for the future. The list is based on information from our own database, which mostly includes funding rounds covered by the media.

Oyo Rooms

Photo credit: Oyo Rooms

A common complaint about budget hotels in India is the major mismatch between the promises of marketing and the reality of accommodation.

Oyo Rooms aims to address that by connecting travelers to a network of budget hotels that meet around 30 standard measures, such as clean bed linen, free WiFi, 24/7 customer support, and air-conditioning in every room.

In September, the startup raised up to US$1 billion in a funding round led by Japan’s SoftBank Vision Fund. This boost will help Oyo expand to markets outside of Asia including the UK, where it plans to sign up 300 independent hotels by the end of 2019.

Paytm (One97)

Vijay Shekhar Sharma, founder and CEO of Paytm / Photo credit: Tech in Asia

This ecommerce and payments platform claims to have pioneered the use of QR-based mobile payments in India. Around 7 million merchants in India use Paytm to receive payments directly into their bank accounts. It expects to soon process one billion transactions per quarter.

Paytm has also been focusing on improving banking compliance. In October, it appointed Satish Kumar Gupta, who had a 30-year stint with the State Bank of India, as the CEO of Paytm Payments Bank.

Meanwhile, it is building an online-to-offline (O2O) model for its marketplace, Paytm Mall.

Valued at US$10 billion, Paytm is owned by One97 Communications, which co-led a US$30 million funding round in February 2017.

PharmEasy

Medication is only a very small part of healthcare, especially for those who have chronic diseases like diabetes. / Photo credit: sheeler / 123RF.

Healthcare is predicted to become a US$280 billion industry in India by 2020. One of the larger digital-first players in this space is PharmEasy, a delivery platform and mobile app that allows users to do things like book diagnostic tests, order medicines, and schedule dosage reminders.

Almost two million people across more than 1,000 cities in India use PharmEasy. The platform, however, has had to deal with sellers of fake medicine. Its top priority now is to solve and eradicate this problem.

In September, PharmEasy raised US$80 million in a series C round led by Eight Roads Ventures India.

Swiggy

Photo credit: Swiggy

India has no shortage of apps that let people order food from restaurants and have it delivered to their doors. Swiggy is one of these platforms, and it processes more monthly orders than archrival Zomato. Around 9,000 restaurants in eight cities have signed up with Swiggy.

This year, Swiggy became a unicorn, achieving a US$1.3 billion valuation just four years after it launched. It also raised US$210 million in a series G round led by Digital Sky Technologies and Naspers Group. The latter is reportedly planning further investment into Swiggy.

Udaan

Photo credit: Comzeal

This B2B marketplace connects 150,000 manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers, and traders. Around 80 percent of buyers on Udaan are small-scale retailers.

After raising US$225 million in a series C round led by Lightspeed Venture Partners and Digital Sky Technologies, the company hit a US$1 billion valuation in September.

Most of the products being sold on Udaan are consumer goods and electronics, but the platform is planning to also include fresh fruit and vegetables, office supplies, and industrial goods.

Ekart Logistics

Photo credit: Forbes India

Ekart, the logistics arm of major online marketplace Flipkart, serves the booming ecommerce sector by providing third-party services to ecommerce companies.

Early this year, Ekart received US$257 million in funding led by Klick2Shop Logistics Services International, another Flipkart-owned company.

Ekart is putting up a 4.5 million-square feet logistics park to consolidate its fulfillment, sorting, and transport activities. The park is expected to be up and running by mid-2019.

PolicyBazaar

Photo credit: scyther5 / 123RF

Anyone who has tried to choose a suitable insurance policy knows the struggle of finding, understanding, and sizing up the options that different companies offer. PolicyBazaar seeks to address this challenge by aggregating and comparing insurance service and policies.

SoftBank Vision Fund led a US$200 million investment in PolicyBazaar in June. More recently, the startup made its first international foray, setting up shop in the United Arab Emirates.

Zomato

Zomato co-founder and CEO Deepinder Goyal / Photo credit: Zomato

Like Swiggy, Zomato enables users to discover restaurants and order food through its platform, which is present in 23 countries worldwide.

When Zomato hit the 10-year mark in July, its founder and CEO Deepinder Goyal took to the company blog to outline his vision for the business. He wrote that Zomato has begun taking steps to become “the biggest farm-to-table food company in the world”.

Investors like Alibaba’s Ant Financial appear to believe in this vision, having led a US$210 million funding round for Zomato in October.

PhonePe

Photo credit: frescomovie / 123RF

Another Flipkart-owned startup, PhonePe is a mobile digital wallet that allows users to transfer money to anyone just by using their phone number. It also allows online payments to companies such as utility service providers.

This year, the platform focused on expanding its service offerings by launching an app-in-app platform. For instance, it partnered with online travel portal Goibibo, and Oyo Rooms to offer hotel bookings. RedBus, an online bus-ticketing platform, has also launched a micro-app within PhonePe.

Flipkart boosted PhonePe’s coffers in March with an infusion of US$79 million.

ReNew Power

Photo credit: Vinoth Chandar

The company generates and supplies energy from renewable resources, such as wind and solar. It is supported by investors such as the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, which led a US$144 million private equity round in January.

ReNew will be developing a 3-MW floating solar photovoltaic project in the state of Andhra Pradesh.

seo.title: The top 10 Indian tech companies to keep an eye on in 2019
seo.description: Venture funding in India has more than doubled from 2017, hitting a total of US$4.3 billion in 2018. And the year isn’t over yet.
